titleStmt.title: M110 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M110 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
Paginated 26-30. On verso of p. 29, a fragment from Between the Acts, paginated 186.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Spenser with his eye upon the reader in the great room.
Yet the audience for all its size and compulsion is silent.

l.add: If we cd. measure the effoect of the audience we shd. have a hold upon the play.

p.l: That is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us
and the play. They crowd there; daily; but they neither

priase praise nor blame. We must compare it with our
won own
sielnce silence

at the Russian ballet or the
cima cinema , in their early days.

A new art comes upon us so
surpinsgly surprisingly that we sit
silent , recognising what we cannot measure.
To the Elizabethans the expressive power of words

after their long inadequacy
ust must have been overwhelming.

There at the
Glove Globe or at the Rose men and women whose only

reading had been the Bible or some old
chonicle chronicle came out
into the light of the present moment. They saw themselves

splendidly dressed. They heard
themslves themselves saying out loud
what they had never said yet. They heard their aspirations,

their profanities, their
ribaldires ribaldries spoken out loud by human
voices in poetry.
The play then owes its hyperbole to the audience in the

pennu seats. At their command it is
vio;ent violent ; it xmxmxmmxmx
it is coarse; it is poexxx xmxmxmxm a parody, of actual
facts. like our own detective stories and best sellers

a
paody parody a
trasnformation transformation of actual fact. But in the seats
in the covered part of the house, there were nobles, rulers,

scholars. Their
silenc silence is harder to explain. For they were
redares readers ; they had the Latins and the Greeks at the back
of their minds. How could it have been that the trained

taste of such
speactoars spectators received the extraordinary
illumination of these English plays with no more comment

netirely entirely in the

Astonihsment Astonishment ; and admiration;

p.l: The soul that walked between delicate groves keeps to a
narrow path between hedges. While Montaigne ranged the world.
micing mixing garrulously with everyone, and speculating freely,
Bacon kept to the narrow path. Yet even in the shade

his thought is embodied. His deep meditations are given
visibe visible

xxxxx concrete form. "Nay
bretire retire men cannot when they would:

quote.l: of privateness even in age and sickness which require the

Shadow; Like old Townsmen that will still be sitting at
ther their
street door, though thereby they offer Age to scorn."

p.l: Even in the delicate grove thought is coloured.

add.quote: The colours that show shew best by candlelight, are: white, carnation, & a kinde of sea-water green

p.l:
His contempt was
fr for hyperbole; not for the art of speech.
He was teaching the ranting players to speak slowly, closely
subtly. He was proving that there is another kind of poetry,

thepoetry the poetry of prose. He was doing his part to bring the
critic critical share in bringing the shade
faculty into being. prose of the mind He was making an end of anonymity. There by [making?]
xxx
Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early

writing a general nature. It gave us the
ballds ballads ; it
gave us the songs. It allowed us to know nothing of the
mans name. Anon had great privileges. He is not
resopnsible. He is not self conscious. He can borrow.

He can repeat. He can say what
very every one feels.
No one asks that he shall stamp his own name on his work.
He keeps at a distance from the present moment.
Anon the lyric poet repeats over and over again

that flowers fade; that death is the
ned end . He is never
tired of celebrating red roses and white breasts.
The anonymous playwright has like the singer this nameless

vitality,
somwthing something drawn from the crowd in the penny

seats and not
yey yet dead in ourselves. For we too become

anonymous
nand and forget something that we have learnt

in reading the
p;ays plays that no one has
troub led troubled to set a
name to.
But at some point there comes a break when anonymity

withdraws. It comes presumably when the
playwrgight playwright has

abosrbed absorbed the
contrbution contribution of the audience; and returns it
to them in a single figure which is individual. There is a

moment in play
aft after play when the audience is no longer
master of the playwright; yet is not separate from him.
A common life still unites them, but the playwright becomes
increasingly diminant. This separation comes fitfully.
Now we say He is speaking our woxmxmxx thoughts.

quote.l: NoO O God, O God that it were possible

To undo
thin s things done; to call back yesterday.

p.l: "But we neednt have been to all that trouble," she Lucy
continued "making the Barn ready, for it didnt rain this
year"
"This year, last year, next year, never..." muttered
old Bartholomew. "Tinker, tailor, soldier, sailor..." He was
talking in his sleep.
Lucy slipped her letter into its envelope. It was time
to read her book---the Outline of History. She had lost her
place. She looked at the pictures; mammoths and mastodons,
and prehistoric birds. Then she found the page where she
had stopped.

The darkness had
incrased increased , and it was cold. With a little

shiver, Mrs Swithin drew her sequin
shawlw shawl about hew shoulders
She was too deep in the story to ask for the window to be

shut. "London" said the author "
a s was then a swamp...

quote.l: Thick groves of trees covered the land, and on the top

p.l: The great square of the window showed only sky now.
It was a losing its light; it was svere severe and stone xxxxx
blue. The shadow crept over Bartholomews face. He looked
leafless, spectral. As a dog shudders its skin, his skin
shuddered. He rose, shook himself, glared at nothing,
and stalked from the room. They hard the dog's paws padding
on the carpet behind him.
Lucy turned the page quickly, guiltily,

like a child who will be told to go to bed before it
raches reaches
the end of the chapter. Pre-historic man, she read, half
human, half monster, rose from his semi-crouching position
Now we note the beauty of the words.
But often it is a suspended, derelict beauty. Chaos inter

venes. The
rl ation relation of part to part is outraged.
The balance is imperfect. Here is profusion; there bareness.

The
anony ous anonymous playwright is irresponsible. He cares nothing
has no conscieince about truth; he cares only for the plot.
We are left in the end without an end. The emotion is e
wasted.

But
graudally gradually the mist withdraws. So many
playwrgihts playwrights

are
explroing exploring So many private people are pressing up

their weight of
unepxpressed unexpressed emotion upon the writers

conscious ess consciousness . Country squires are finding
themsleves themselves able
to say what they think without quoting Spenser.

The
curatin curtain rises
incesaantly incessantly upon play after play.

l.add: Every each time, with [illeg.] it rises upon a more complex, highly matured drama.

p.l: After it has risen again and again it rises finally upon
upon the completely embodied; and upon the completely

controlled. It rises upon Hamlet and
Cleoptara Cleopatra and
Flastaff Falstaff
and Macbeth. Finally it rises upon the Tempest. But the play
has outgrown the uncovered theatre where the sun beats and
the rain pours. The theatre must be replaced
by the theatre of the brain. Anon is replaced by the man
who writes a book. The audience is replaced by the the
reader. Anon, when is dead.
